just.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: A good strong cup of coffee is just what I need right now.
The house was large and roomy; just right for us.
She looks just like her mother.
Just what do you think you’re trying to do?
Just then (=exactly at that moment), Mrs Robovitch appeared at the bedroom door.
Just as (=at the exact moment when) I opened the door, the telephone started to ring.
A nice hot bath – just the thing (=exactly the right thing) to relax sore muscles.
just.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: nothing more than the thing, amount, action etc that you are mentioning
just.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: It’s nothing serious – just a small cut.
Don’t be too hard on him – he’s just a kid.
Can you wait just a few minutes?
It’s not just me – there are other people involved as well.
just.translation[0].definitions[1].note_: In written English, people often prefer to use simply rather than just, which sounds rather informal:
It’s simply a question of priorities.
just.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: John’s just told me that he’s getting married.
just.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: at this moment or at that moment
just.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Wait a minute – I’m just coming.
He was just leaving when the phone rang.
I’m just finishing my homework – it won’t take long.
The concert was just about to start.
just.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: I just love being in the mountains.
It was just wonderful to see Joyce again.
I just wish I could believe you.
just.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: only by a small amount, time, distance etc
just.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: I saw her just before she died.
It’s just under three centimetres long.
We moved here just after our son was born.
just.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: used to show that something which happens almost does not happen
just.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: He just managed to get home before dark.
We could just see the coast of France in the distance.
Those pants only just fit you now.
She was earning just enough money to live on  (=enough but not more than enough).
just.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: used when politely asking something or telling someone to do something
just.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Could I just say a few words before we start?
Would you just explain to us how the system works.
just.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: used when firmly telling someone to do something
just.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Look, just shut up for a minute!
Now, just listen to what I’m telling you.
just.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: Just comes before a main verb
just.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: Just comes after ‘be’ when it is the main verb
just.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: Just comes after the first auxiliary verb
just.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Henry sincerely believed that he was fighting a just war.
Charlemagne was respected as a just ruler.
just.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: a just reward for their loyal service
What would be a just punishment for such a crime?
I hope that he’s caught and gets his just deserts (=is punished in the way he deserves).
